1.text:
Q&A
Malcolm Grant: I have a magnificent team to

12.text:
field the questions that will be coming from
you. Also, let me suggest some terms of engagement.

19.text:
In a moment I will briefly introduce the members
of the board. However, I would ask anyone

24.text:
who asks a question to please observe the
normal courtesies of introducing yourself

28.text:
and saying who you are and where you're from.
Then I would like to perhaps marshal two or

34.text:
three questions at a time and then allocate
them to the best-qualified member of the board

39.text:
to answer them.
Please may I just introduce my colleagues.

43.text:
On the far right is Jo-Anne Woss, who is our
personnel director; Tim Kelsey, I think you

49.text:
have already seen in action; Dame Barbara
Hakin, who is our Deputy Chief Executive.

54.text:
Those three are our Executive Directors.
The difference between executive directors

61.text:
and non-executive directors is that the executive
directors do all of the work, they are full-time,

68.text:
salaried members of the board; the non-executive
directors come in from time to time and bully

74.text:
the executive directors. That is a very brief
description.

78.text:
I will continue with the executive team: Jane
Cummings, the Chief Nursing Officer; you have

83.text:
heard from Sir Bruce Keogh, our Medical Director;
Ros Roughton, Director of Commissioning; you

90.text:
have just heard from Bill McCarthy, our Policy
Director, and you have heard the outstanding

99.text:
Finance Director and the Chief Executive,
of whom I shall say no more.

104.text:
Now, let me come back to the non-executive
directors: Ciarán Devane, who is also Chief

111.text:
Executive of Macmillan cancer care, so he
brings a great wealth of experience from the

115.text:
voluntary sector; Ed Smith, who has a wide
portfolio but is actually a former senior

123.text:
partner of PWC, but chairs World Wildlife
Fund UK and Birmingham University; Moira Gibb,

129.text:
who has a great length of experience with
social care and local government and is the

136.text:
former chief executive of the London borough
of Camden; Margaret Casely-Hayford is the

141.text:
Company Secretary and Director of Legal Services
for the John Lewis Partnership, another great

147.text:
social institution is this country, with a
real understanding of values and of consumers;

153.text:
and Naguib Kheraj who works closely with the
Aga Khan in the Aga Khan Foundation. That

160.text:
is the team.
Now let me invite questions from the floor.

171.text:
Please, it is over to you.
John Woolgrove: Thank you, my name is John

186.text:
Woolgrove; I am now retired but I did work
for the NHS for many years. I am very impressed

191.text:
with David Nicholson's suggestion for transparency
and openness, and I think this should extend

196.text:
to all areas of the NHS. With that in mind,
I wondered whether the senior members of the

206.text:
NHS, who are marshalled before us now, would
be prepared to declare whether they have all

210.text:
of their own treatment from the NHS or if
they sometimes seek private care. If they

216.text:
did seek private care, it would be illuminating
to know their reasons for doing that.

221.text:
Simon Chapman: Hello, I am Simon Chapman,
from the National Council for Palliative Care

233.text:
and the Dying Matters coalition. Firstly,
thank you very much to NHS England for organising

238.text:
today; having been here all day, I think that
for a first AGM it has been interesting and

246.text:
illuminating. Thank you and well done; thank
you for putting end of life care on your agenda.

250.text:
It has been really interesting to hear the
feedback from all of the workshops. There

256.text:
has been a lot of feedback today and, actually,
NHS England has had a lot of feedback in many

263.text:
consultations over the last year or so, as
have other statutory bodies. This time next

268.text:
year will you tell us how you have acted on
the today's feedback? Will there be session

274.text:
along the lines of 'you said, we did?'
Ahmed: Hello, my name is Ahmed. I wear multiple

290.text:
hats; I have had the opportunity to be of
service to the NHS back in the days of the

296.text:
National Programme, trying to understand addressability
between the commissioning and the suppliers

301.text:
who are delivering the programme. I have also
been involved in improving that addressability

304.text:
framework. However, more recently I have made
myself useful as a lay person on the cure

311.text:
review and I have also ended up being the
only lay-chair for the CCG authorisation process.

322.text:
I am also an elected Public Governor; one
of the very few elected officers who are not

327.text:
politicians or party-political in any way.
Tim came to the Foundation Trust Governors'

335.text:
Association's meeting last year; when he was
on the Commissioning Board Authority Special

342.text:
Health Authority. I asked him that it was
all very well for people who are sick and

347.text:
need care, and of course the NHS is there
to serve them, but at the end of the day it

352.text:
is a health service; I think its primary goal
is to keep people healthy, happy and to enable

357.text:
them to live long and prosperous lives. So,
what are you doing about that? At that time

362.text:
Tim's answer had been along the lines of,
'It is to do with Public Health England, it

366.text:
has nothing to do with us.' Of course, since
then you have changed your name. You are now

371.text:
NHS England; you are Health Service for England.
Has the situation changed? How are you working

376.text:
together with Public Health England? What
about people who want to stay healthy?

381.text:
Malcolm Grant: Do you want to put that question
to Mr Kelsey again? Shall we start with Tim;

386.text:
I will take the questions in reverse order,
if I may?

391.text:
Tim Kelsey: I am surprised if I said that
that belonged to Public Health England because

399.text:
one of the biggest parts of my responsibility
is precisely to provide information to patients

404.text:
and the public so that can take control of
their own health when they wish to. Already

411.text:
we have been publishing, as we referred to
earlier, vast amounts of information alongside

417.text:
all sorts of online and other services, so
that people can, when they wish, make the

422.text:
most of taking control of their own health
and wellbeing for themselves. Public Health

426.text:
England clearly has a fundamentally important
role to play, as well.

431.text:
However, to be clear, in the promotion of
this vision of putting the patient at the

436.text:
heart of healthcare, a really important part
of that is to empower people with the tools,

440.text:
services and information that they need, among
other things, to take precisely that control

445.text:
over their health and wellbeing. Therefore,
my answer is that it is a top priority for

449.text:
us; hold us to account for delivering it over
the next year. We are really working on it.

453.text:
Malcolm Grant: Can I take the question from
Simon Chapman, which was, 'You said, we did.'

459.text:
What are we going to say to you next year,
as we sit here, in relation to what we have

464.text:
heard from you tonight? Bill, I wonder if
you might venture a response to that one.

473.text:
Bill McCarthy: A couple of points: you said
it is a 'you said, we did.' It has been lived-streamed,

481.text:
so in regards to the thoughts that we could
brush this aside and forget about it, even

491.text:
if we were so inclined it would be impossible.
In a sense, you have the documentary evidence

497.text:
to check how we act on this exercise today.
My second point is that our ambitions are

504.text:
actually higher than that. This is not a one-off,
really important event where we listen to

516.text:
a set of workshops and then off we go to do
our work until next year. This is genuinely

522.text:
the start of a much more open, continually
engaging, evolving process. So, as Olivia

529.text:
was saying, there are other events happening
around the country today. We are expecting

537.text:
all of our Health and Wellbeing partners to
be working with us in every community around

542.text:
the country in order to understand, hear and
listen to the priorities, the concerns and

548.text:
the aspirations of local people, and act upon
them. All of that will then get captured in

555.text:
the planning around the visions, which will
be put out locally.

559.text:
So, anchoring into the transparency that David
and Tim have talked about, it will be there

566.text:
for you to see and to check up on. This is
not us coming out for a day in the sun and

571.text:
then popping back into a shed somewhere. This
is the start of an open and engaged process,

579.text:
where you will be able to hold us to account;
both for the good things we achieve and, to

584.text:
be honest, for the things we had hoped to
do and were unable to.

587.text:
Malcolm Grant: Thank you very much for that,
Bill.

590.text:
The first question we were asked, from John
Woolgrove, related to treatment form the NHS.

595.text:
As far as I know, all of my colleagues do
turn to the NHS for their treatment. I chose

600.text:
a particular route which I do not think is
available to everybody, which is that I married

606.text:
my GP. This brought all of the necessary services
in-house and I have never been allowed a day

618.text:
off work since, nor have our children. I simply
take that as read so far as the board is concerned.

626.text:
Now, please may I take another clutch 
of questions?

638.text:
Inga Wallace: Hi, my name is Inga Wallace,
stroke survivor with aphasia, so bear with

648.text:
me. I am a patient involved in lots of the
NHS. I have an observation rather than a question:

663.text:
all day, and seeing the board tonight, I have
wondered, 'Where are the young people?' It

670.text:
is a new world; they have been brought up
in the new world and they expect different

677.text:
things in the world than we have been brought
up to expect. As a mother of people in their

685.text:
twenties, and having been a teacher in a pupil
referral unit of young people who are challenging

694.text:
but amazing, I think there is a resource out
there of fabulous ideas-makers aged between

703.text:
12 and 30, which I really hope this board
will engage with through focus groups.

711.text:
To be honest, this time next year I would
like to see someone on that stage aged under

716.text:
30, because one of the ways forward, for seven-day
services and the like, is about collaboration

727.text:
and communication. Younger people are geniuses
at brainstorming ideas and ways of working;

738.text:
it comes naturally to them. They are an asset
that I am not quite seeing yet.

747.text:
That is just an observation for you, and I
hope, as a person with a daughter of epilepsy,

755.text:
who has been in and out of NHS services, that
you would think about young people. She has

761.text:
got opinions but she has nowhere to take them,
and nobody is attracting her in a way that

768.text:
attracts her. So please think about young
people.

772.text:
Malcolm Grant: Thank you very much for that.
My apologies for the ageing population on

782.text:
the platform, but had you been here earlier
when we had the whizz-kids; they were absolutely

789.text:
fabulous. I was really moved by what we heard
from them. Please, we are not overlooking

795.text:
that group at all.
Tim Kelsey: If I can just add something. The

803.text:
team that has organised this event is just
about to launch a major initiative for young

807.text:
people, which is absolutely recognising the
vision and energy that we need to glean from

814.text:
all kinds of patients and citizens and so
on.

818.text:
Also, of course, another point: Jane has done
some fantastic work getting together volunteers

823.text:
to be care-makers, rather like the Olympic
model, so we are really aware of the absolute

829.text:
importance of working with everybody, but
especially with young people.

835.text:
Malcolm Grant: Thank you very much. I would
like to take a few more questions and we will

840.text:
cluster them together and we will answer everything
we can. I am sorry if we do not get right

844.text:
across the room.
Thomas Harrington: Good evening, my name is

851.text:
Thomas Harrington. Can you tell me how you
see mental health service developing over

856.text:
the next ten years?
Joan Davis: Thank you. I represent the Community

867.text:
Voice, which is an umbrella organisation in
North-West London and South-West Hertfordshire;

874.text:
totally independent, but totally dedicated
to good NHS services.

881.text:
I am surprised that we have heard so little
about NHS England's role at a local level.

890.text:
In the past we have had meetings held in public
where we could know what was happening locally,

898.text:
but there is no equivalent to board meetings
in public at a regional level. However, in

906.text:
fact, you provide specialised services which
are of huge importance to local people. So

912.text:
my plea is, when will you hold local public
meetings, where, if possible, your officials

921.text:
can not only give information but can also
hear the views of local people?

933.text:
I have written to you three times, Malcolm,
and await a response.

937.text: Stephen Bubb: Stephen Bubb, I run ACEVO, the

953.text:
charities' leaders' network. My question is
for Ciarán. I have loved the many references

959.text:
tonight to the role of the third sector, I
just wonder how big or small do you think

967.text:
the rhetoric-reality gap is?
Gilbert Wheeler: Hello, good evening, my name

990.text:
is Gilbert Wheeler and I am a patient; I work
for a charity on a voluntary basis. Is the

998.text:
board aware that today the CQC held a similar
event as you have held here? There were many

1004.text:
good aspects of today that came out, and they
are looking at various subjects that we have

1010.text:
raised today; possibly the evolvement of a
patients' panel, reviewing hospitals and other

1019.text:
areas. There are lots of things that are coming
out of this meeting today that will probably

1023.text:
come to light in time. I just wondered if
the board was aware that this meeting had

1027.text:
also taken place today. Thank you.
Malcolm Grant: Thank you very much. May I

1031.text:
now field some of these questions to my colleagues.
The first one was Inga Wells, which was the

1039.text:
question about young people. I think we have
had a response to that from Tim, so if I may,

1043.text:
I think we will move on from that.
Thomas Harrison asked about what mental health

1049.text:
services would look like in ten years. Bruce,
I wonder whether you might help us to respond

1054.text:
to that.
Bruce Keogh: Thank you. The first thing to

1057.text:
say is that we are developing a mental health
strategy and we will be asking people to help

1062.text:
us with that. However, the starting point
is that the importance of mental health has,

1070.text:
I think, been historically undervalued, both
in society and the NHS.

1073.text:
For me, a turning point during the course
of my career was a recognition that mental

1081.text:
health was also strongly associated with early
mortality and other noticeable, physical conditions.

1089.text:
For example, today we heard that people with
schizophrenia are 90 times more likely to

1094.text:
get colorectal cancer; we know that it is
associated with an increased incidence of

1101.text:
cardiovascular disease because people smoke
more, etc. The impact of mental health has

1107.text:
been increasingly recognised on what might
be otherwise deemed as unrelated physical

1112.text:
conditions. I think that will help to drive
the thought processes of clinicians in the

1118.text:
NHS.
However, importantly, I think we are going

1120.text:
to see more self-care and we are going to
see much more integrated care in the community.

1127.text:
I do worry sometimes about the fracture between
community care in mental health and hospital

1132.text:
care; accountability and the way those services
are integrated.

1140.text:
One of the things that also niggles at me,
that I do not think we have really gotten

1144.text:
to grips with, is that mental health problems
in one individual become a problem for the

1152.text:
whole family. It can be a familial disease
in that sense.

1161.text:
I think we have got a lot of work to do in
terms of mental health. Our biggest challenge

1166.text:
is probably actually changing public and internal
NHS perceptions about its importance.

1172.text:
Malcolm Grant: Thank you very much. Joan Davis's
question was about local services and open

1178.text:
meetings at a local level; we have not really
spoken much today about CCGs but, given that

1182.text:
David mentioned them, may I call upon him
to respond.

1186.text:
David Nicholson: This whole issue about the
way in which we interact with the public is

1193.text:
one which I think we are building and learning
as we go along.

1198.text:
Of course, at a local level clinical commissioning
groups are our main base on which we would

1204.text:
expect those conversations to go on. As many
of you know, many, if not all clinical commissioning

1210.text:
groups have mechanisms to speak to their local
people. Increasingly, I think we will see

1220.text:
engagement and discussion at a Health and
Wellbeing board level, and NHS England is

1228.text:
part of every Health and Wellbeing board.
If you think about the future there are going

1233.text:
to be many of the big decisions regarding
issues such as the way in which the resources

1237.text:
are going to be transferred from the NHS,
to our social care and the way the integration

1245.text:
fund is going to be built up. Those discussions
will take place at Health and Wellbeing board

1248.text:
level. I think there is an issue about how
Health and Wellbeing boards engage with the

1253.text:
public.
The third issue is NHS England's specific

1258.text:
commissioning arrangements. I have to say
that we have not quite gotten to the end of

1263.text:
our debate on that. I am really sorry that
you have written to the Chairman three times

1268.text:
and have no received a reply; I cannot imagine
why that is and we will get onto that straightaway.

1273.text:
However, it is something that has been raised
by our own staff in the sense that they realise

1279.text:
that they are engaged at a regional or a local
area level, and are making really quite significant

1286.text:
decisions. They have identified a gap in the
way in which they operate, and we are very

1294.text:
keen to think about how we could fill that
gap in a constructive and helpful way. Certainly,

1300.text:
I think that this is one of those things that,
as you were saying, we do. I think we should

1305.text:
take that away and think really carefully
about how we can get that engagement at that

1310.text:
level, because it is in both of our interests
for that to happen. If we are really true

1316.text:
to transparency, that is exactly what we should
do.

1318.text:
Malcolm Grant: Thank you very much. We now
turn to the Ciarán Devane question, which

1323.text:
was asked by Stephen Bubb, and that is, 'What
is the difference between the rhetoric and

1327.text:
the reality?'
Ciarán Devane: Thank you, I am sure Bruce

1331.text:
will have an opinion as well. If we go back
to the white paper, Dave, before the future

1337.text:
forum, I would have said I was quite worried,
because I think the white paper really projected

1344.text:
engagement with patients and the public as
a very consumer thing, which is good, but

1348.text:
it is not sufficient. I did not feel at the
time that there was enough of an emphasis

1353.text:
of listening to patients and patient organisations
at a policy level and service design level.

1361.text:
If I take the mental photograph now, I think
we have moved on hugely. I think my short

1367.text:
answer is that the gap is whatever we allow
it to be. If I can be voluntary sector for

1373.text:
a moment; I think we have come a long way,
because we have to demonstrate our value in

1379.text:
terms of insight, in terms of data, in terms
of research, the end of life question and

1386.text:
in terms of the services that the hospices
and the Marie Curie's of the world can provide.

1390.text:
However, I think we have to be very assertive
in doing that; confident. Also, we must make

1394.text:
sure that not only at NHS England on a national
level, but by CCG and Health and Wellbeing

1402.text:
board, that we get it right.
I think I pointed at some very good examples.

1409.text:
I think the fact that the board of NHS England
does have two Chief Executives of voluntary

1416.text:
organisations on it, clearly shows that NHS
England wants to listen. Neil Churchill, who

1422.text:
is the Chief Executive of Asthma UK, is now
one of the domain leads looking after patient

1427.text:
experience. Thus, I think the relationship,
the thinking and the openness is much, much

1434.text:
better than I feared. However, being voluntary
sector for a moment, I think it is up to us;

1439.text:
I think we have to demonstrate our value intellectually,
in the knowledge that we bring, and also in

1445.text:
the quality of the services that we provide.
However, it has come an awful long way.

1451.text:
Bruce Keogh: There is no rhetoric in my mind,
Stephen, and I should declare an interest:

1457.text:
I am on the council of the British Heart Foundation.
They have paid for a considerable amount of

1461.text:
research that I have done over the years;
they have paid for a year of my salary as

1466.text:
a research fellow and for several years of
my salary as a consultant.

1472.text:
One of the things that I have learnt from
that close association with a major charity

1477.text:
is that, first of all, they understand what
patients want. Secondly, they are trusted

1484.text:
by patients. Thirdly, they are not subject
to any kind of external influences that might

1490.text:
make them take one view or another. Finally,
they conduct and fund some of the finest research

1496.text:
in the world.
I think that they have been a grossly under-utilised

1502.text:
resource in the NHS for a considerable period
of time. During the course of my time as NHS

1510.text:
Medical Director, I had meetings with chief
executives of some of the big charities, asking

1517.text:
them to help us with policy. Indeed, David
Nicholson and I had a meeting with the Chief

1523.text:
Executive of one of the big charities the
other day and asked a group, called the Richmond

1527.text:
Group, which consists of the chief executives
of many of the big charities, to help us not

1533.text:
only with policy development, but with how
we can improve the delivery of services to

1538.text:
patients.
Malcolm Grant: Thank you very much, Bruce.

1541.text:
The last question, which was from Gilbert
Wheeler, asked whether we were aware of the

1545.text:
CQC event today. I can assure you that none
of this board were at the CQC event, because

1551.text:
I had them all locked in a room while we went
through an extensive board meeting today.

1556.text:
However, of course we work very closely with
the CQC, the Care Quality Commission, as we

1561.text:
do with all our other arm's-length partners.
One of the great difficulties is that there

1566.text:
is a fragmentation of responsibility for different
aspects of total care across the whole of

1573.text:
the NHS; with CQC, with Monitor, with NICE
and also, of course, reaching out into local

1579.text:
government and our partnership with them.
We are committed to making that partnership

1583.text:
work; it is quite difficult at times, when
you have autonomous arm's-length bodies all

1589.text:
trying to achieve things within their own
terms of reference.

1592.text:
However, it is our responsibility to draw
the whole of this operation together and to

1598.text:
make sure there is clarity. Clarity about
our objectives is only going to be achieved

1602.text:
if we have developed those objectives in consultation
with public and patients, and that is what

1607.text:
this evening and, indeed, the whole of today
has been about.

1610.text:
I am going to draw the proceedings to a close,
now. However, before I do, I have got to issue

1616.text:
some warm thanks. First of all, to Olivia
Butterworth and to all the participants in

1621.text:
those workshops this afternoon; people gave
up their time voluntarily. They did not have

1625.text:
to come here; they gave up their time because
they want to make the NHS better and better

1630.text:
all the time. We owe you an enormous debt
and are enormously grateful for all that you

1635.text:
have done and for all of those wonderful presentations
earlier. Therefore, thank you all very much.

1644.text:
Secondly, of course, I must thank my board,
or I will be in difficulty with them, for

1654.text:
answering your questions so openly and honestly
tonight.

1657.text:
Thirdly, the real thanks go to you. You have
come, you have given of your time and, I think,

1663.text:
you are anxious to watch us to develop, and
we will develop. I hope to see everybody here

1668.text:
next year, and we will do the 'you said, we
did,' because we are a growing organisation.

1675.text:
Please take this evening as a pledge to the
openness that we regard as being at the heart

1680.text:
of everything we do.
I am frustrated that we did not have longer.

1684.text:
You are frustrated that we were not able to
take all of the questions; we are willing

1688.text:
to linger informally now and to talk informally
to those of you who would like to do that.

1693.text:
However, may I, in the interests of drawing
the proceedings to a close now, say the AGM

1699.text:
-- the first AGM -- the first ever AGM of
NHS England is now closed. Thank you so much
